description: From Middle English knowleche, knaweleche, cnawlece (“knowledge”), from knowen (“to know, recognise”) + -leche. Related to Middle English knowlechen (“to find out, acknowledge”). For more on the Middle English suffix -leche, compare freelage. Compare also Old English cnāwelǣċ, cnāwelǣċing (“acknowledging, acknowledgement”).

entries.meaning: The fact of knowing about something; general understanding or familiarity with a subject, place, situation etc. [from 14th c.]
Awareness of a particular fact or situation; a state of having been informed or made aware of something. [from 14th c.]
Intellectual understanding; the state of appreciating truth or information. [from 14th c.]
Familiarity or understanding of a particular skill, branch of learning etc. [from 14th c.]
(philosophical) Justified true belief
(archaic or law) Sexual intimacy or intercourse (now usually in phrase carnal knowledge). [from 15th c.]
(obsolete) Information or intelligence about something; notice. [15th–18th c.]
The total of what is known; all information and products of learning. [from 16th c.]
(countable) Something that can be known; a branch of learning; a piece of information; a science. [from 16th c.]
(obsolete) Acknowledgement. [14th–16th c.]
(obsolete) Notice, awareness. [17th c.]
(UK, informal) The deep familiarity with certain routes and places of interest required by taxicab drivers working in London, England.
The fact of knowing about something; general understanding or familiarity with a subject, place, situation etc. [from 14th c.]
examples: His knowledge of Iceland was limited to what he'd seen on the Travel Channel.

entries.meaning: Awareness of a particular fact or situation; a state of having been informed or made aware of something. [from 14th c.]
Intellectual understanding; the state of appreciating truth or information. [from 14th c.]
examples: Knowledge consists in recognizing the difference between good and bad decisions.

entries.meaning: Familiarity or understanding of a particular skill, branch of learning etc. [from 14th c.]
examples: Does your friend have any knowledge of hieroglyphs, perchance?
A secretary should have a good knowledge of shorthand.

entries.meaning: (philosophical) Justified true belief
(archaic or law) Sexual intimacy or intercourse (now usually in phrase carnal knowledge). [from 15th c.]
(obsolete) Information or intelligence about something; notice. [15th–18th c.]
examples: Item, if any ship be in danger […], every man to bear towards her, answering her with one light for a short time, and so to put it out again; thereby to give knowledge that they have seen her token.

entries.meaning: The total of what is known; all information and products of learning. [from 16th c.]
examples: His library contained the accumulated knowledge of the Greeks and Romans.

entries.meaning: (countable) Something that can be known; a branch of learning; a piece of information; a science. [from 16th c.]
examples: There is a great difference in the delivery of the mathematics, which are the most abstracted of knowledges.

entries.meaning: (obsolete) Acknowledgement. [14th–16th c.]
(obsolete) Notice, awareness. [17th c.]
(UK, informal) The deep familiarity with certain routes and places of interest required by taxicab drivers working in London, England.

verbs.description: knowledge (third-person singular simple present knowledges, present participle knowledging, simple past and past participle knowledged)

entries.meaning: (obsolete) To confess as true; to acknowledge. [13th–17th c.]
